question: A.001 [1.0 point] {1.0} During a fuel loading of the core, as the reactor approaches criticality, the value of 1/M:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Module 4, ℞ Theory (℞ Operations), E.O. 1.4, pg. 7 and DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volumes 1 and 2, January 1993.
Incorrect. Reference: Module 4, ℞ Theory (℞ Operations), E.O. 1.4, pg. 7 and DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volumes 1 and 2, January 1993.
Incorrect. Reference: Module 4, ℞ Theory (℞ Operations), E.O. 1.4, pg. 7 and DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volumes 1 and 2, January 1993.
Correct. Reference: Module 4, ℞ Theory (℞ Operations), E.O. 1.4, pg. 7 and DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volumes 1 and 2, January 1993.

question: A.002 [1.0 point] {2.0} Which one of the following accurately details a factor contributing to Xenon balance within the reactor?

answers.answer: a. Most Xe135 is formed by fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: b. Te135 is a fission product which quickly decays to I135.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: c. Within approximately 8 hours after startup, Xe135 has reached its equilibrium value.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: d. Several minutes following a reactor shutdown, Xe level is increasing because I135 is not being produced.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

question: A.003 [1.0 point] {3.0} Given a fuel temperature coefficient of -1.25 × 10-4 ΔK/K/°C.  When a control rod with an average worth of 0.1% ΔK/K/inch is withdrawn 10 inches, reactor power increases and becomes stable at a higher level.  At this point fuel temperature has … (neglect power coefficient)

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: A.004 [1.0 point] {4.0} Which ONE of the following conditions will DECREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Increase moderator temperature (Assume negative temperature coefficient)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question

answers.answer: c. Burnout of a burnable poison
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Standard NRC question
Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC question

question: A.005 [1.0 point] {5.0} Reactor power is rising on a 30 second period.  Approximately how long will it take for power to double?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, P = P0 et/T  –> ln (2) = time ÷ 30 sec –> time = ln (2) x 30 sec. 0.693 x 30  ≈ 0.7 x 30 ≈ 21 sec
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, P = P0 et/T  –> ln (2) = time ÷ 30 sec –> time = ln (2) x 30 sec. 0.693 x 30  ≈ 0.7 x 30 ≈ 21 sec
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, P = P0 et/T  –> ln (2) = time ÷ 30 sec –> time = ln (2) x 30 sec. 0.693 x 30  ≈ 0.7 x 30 ≈ 21 sec
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, P = P0 et/T  –> ln (2) = time ÷ 30 sec –> time = ln (2) x 30 sec. 0.693 x 30  ≈ 0.7 x 30 ≈ 21 sec

question: A.006 [1.0 point] {6.0} Reactor power is increasing on a constant positive reactor period.  Which ONE of the following power changes would finish in the shortest time?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume

question: A.007 [1.0 point] {7.0} The Moderating Ratio measures the effectiveness of a moderator by combining the scattering cross section, the absorption cross section, and the average energy loss per collision.  The Moderating Ratio is expressed as:

answers.answer: a. (absorption cross section)x(scattering cross section)/(average energy loss per collision).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 2, Neutron Moderation,  page 28.

answers.answer: b. (absorption cross section)x(average energy loss per collision)/(scattering cross section).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 2, Neutron Moderation,  page 28.

answers.answer: c. (scattering cross section)x(absorption cross section)x(average energy loss per collision).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 2, Neutron Moderation,  page 28.

answers.answer: d. (average energy loss per collision)x(scattering cross section)/(absorption cross section).
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 2, Neutron Moderation,  page 28.

question: A.008 [1.0 point] {8.0} Inelastic scattering can be described as a process whereby a neutron collides with a nucleus and:

answers.answer: a. reappears with a lower kinetic energy, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 1, Neutron Interactions,  page 45.

answers.answer: b. reappears with the same kinetic energy it had prior to the collision.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 1, Neutron Interactions,  page 45.

answers.answer: c. is absorbed by the nucleus, with the nucleus emitting a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 1, Neutron Interactions,  page 45.

answers.answer: d. reappears with a higher kinetic energy, with the nucleus absorbing a gamma ray.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 1, Neutron Interactions,  page 45.

question: A.009 [1.0 point] {9.0} Which ONE of the following describes the difference between prompt and delayed neutrons?  Prompt neutrons …

answers.answer: a. account for less than 1% of the neutron population, while delayed neutrons account for the rest.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: b. are released only during fast-fission events, while delayed neutrons are released during the decay process.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: c. are released during the fission process (fast & thermal), while delayed neutrons are released during the decay process.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: d. are the dominating factor in determining reactor period, while delayed neutrons have little effect on reactor period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: A.010 [1.0 point] {10.0} To make a just critical reactor “PROMPT CRITICAL”, by definition you must add reactivity equal to

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.8
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.8
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.8
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.8

question: A.011 [1.0 point] {11.0} What is the period that would cause reactor power to double in 40 seconds?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z  P = P0 et/T   ln(P/P0) = t/T  T= t/ln(P/P0)  T = 30 sec/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 57.7 sec

Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z  P = P0 et/T   ln(P/P0) = t/T  T= t/ln(P/P0)  T = 30 sec/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 57.7 sec

Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z  P = P0 et/T   ln(P/P0) = t/T  T= t/ln(P/P0)  T = 30 sec/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 57.7 sec

Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z  P = P0 et/T   ln(P/P0) = t/T  T= t/ln(P/P0)  T = 30 sec/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 57.7 sec

question: A.012 [1.0 point] {12.0} A reactor has a moderator temperature coefficient of reactivity is 1.0 x 10-4 ΔK/K/ C.  If the average coolant temperature decreases by 10C, a regulating rod with a differential rod worth of 0.05%ΔK/K/inch must be ______________ to maintain the same power.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

question: A.013 [1.0 point] {13.0} A reactor is subcritical with a Keff of 0.955.  If you add 4.5% Δk/k of positive reactivity into the core, the reactor will be …

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 1.3
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 1.3
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 1.3
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 1.3

question: A.014 [1.0 point] {14.0} The PRIMARY reason that a neutron source is installed in the reactor is to …

answers.answer: a. allow for testing and irradiation of experiments when the core is shutdown.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 3.1

answers.answer: b. supply the neutrons required to start the chain reaction for subsequent reactor startups.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 3.1

answers.answer: c. provide a neutron level high enough to be monitored for a controlled reactor startup.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 3.1

answers.answer: d. increase the excess reactivity of the reactor which reduces the frequency for refueling.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 3.1

question: A.015 [1.0 point] {15.0} Which ONE of the following describes the difference between a moderator and reflector?

answers.answer: a. A reflector increases the fast non-leakage factor and a moderator increases the thermal utilization factor.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), pp. 25-26

answers.answer: b. A reflector increases the neutron production factor and a moderator increases the fast fission factor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), pp. 25-26

answers.answer: c. A reflector decreases the thermal utilization factor and a moderator increases the fast fission factor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), pp. 25-26

answers.answer: d. A reflector decreases the neutron production factor and a moderator decreases the fast non-leakage factor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), pp. 25-26

question: A.016 [1.0 point] {16.0} A few minutes after a reactor scram period has steadied and reactor power is at 5 × 105 counts/minute.  Three minutes later you would expect reactor power to be at …

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: This is an 80 second period which implies power decreases by ~ ⅓ decade per minute, in 3 minutes power will decrease by 1 decade.  DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2

Incorrect. Reference: This is an 80 second period which implies power decreases by ~ ⅓ decade per minute, in 3 minutes power will decrease by 1 decade.  DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2

Correct. Reference: This is an 80 second period which implies power decreases by ~ ⅓ decade per minute, in 3 minutes power will decrease by 1 decade.  DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2

Incorrect. Reference: This is an 80 second period which implies power decreases by ~ ⅓ decade per minute, in 3 minutes power will decrease by 1 decade.  DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2

question: A.017 [1.0 point] {17.0} A reactor has a count rate of 45 cps with a Keff of 0.965. Which one of the following is the Keff of this reactor when the count rate increases to 90 cps?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 45(1-Keff1) = 90(1 –Keff2) Keff2 = 0.9825
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 45(1-Keff1) = 90(1 –Keff2) Keff2 = 0.9825
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 45(1-Keff1) = 90(1 –Keff2) Keff2 = 0.9825
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 45(1-Keff1) = 90(1 –Keff2) Keff2 = 0.9825

question: A.018 [1.0 point] {18.0} Which ONE of the following is the correct definition of βeffective?  The number of delayed neutrons compared to the total number of neutrons per generation …

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.2
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.2

answers.answer: c. corrected for time after the fission event.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.2

answers.answer: d. corrected for both leakage and resonance escape.
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, Reactor Theory (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 2.2

question: A.019 [1.0 point] {19.0} Which ONE of the following factors is the most significant in determining the differential worth of a control rod?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 5.4
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 5.4
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 5.4

answers.answer: d. The amount of fuel in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, (Reactor Operations), Enabling Objective 5.4

question: A.020 [1.0 point] {20.0} During a reactor startup, the count rate is increasing linearly on a logarithmic scale, with no rod motion.  This means that:

answers.answer: a. the reactor is subcritical and the count rate increase is due to the buildup of delayed neutron precursors.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 4, Reactor Kinetics, page 14.

answers.answer: b. the reactor is subcritical and the count rate increase is due to source neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 4, Reactor Kinetics, page 14.

answers.answer: c. the reactor is critical and the count rate increase is due to source neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 4, Reactor Kinetics, page 14.
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 4, Reactor Kinetics, page 14.
